node.text:
As New Yorkers commemorate the 20th anniversary of 9/11, they are also contemplating how to recover from covid-19.

After the attacks of 2001, New York came back stronger—so what lessons can its leaders learn from that success to help the city bounce back today?

Cover image credit: Gary Hershorn/Getty Images

node.title: From 9/11 to covid-19: can New York recover?

node.text:
The pandemic not only disrupted education—it also thrust technology onto a sector which historically has been slow to adopt it. Will classrooms ever be the same again?

Cover image credit: Ben Hasty/MediaNews Group/Reading Eagle via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: how tech will transform your kids’ education

buttons.text: Visit the COVID-19 Information Center for vaccine resources.

node.text: The race between covid-19 vaccines and variants is on. Alok Jha, The Economist’s science correspondent, and Natasha Loder, our health policy editor, discuss what this means for the future. Cover image credit: Alamy

node.title: Covid-19: can vaccines keep up with variants?

node.text: The Taliban’s swift return to power in Afghanistan has shocked the world and humiliated America. What effect will this have on the international standing of the US and on global security? Our experts answer your questions. Cover credit: AP

node.title: Afghanistan: how the Taliban weakened America

node.text:
Most governments recognise that vaccination is the fastest way out of the pandemic, but in many places hesitancy is hindering the roll-out. Should employers—or even governments—force people to have the vaccine? We answer your questions.

Cover image credit:

node.text:
The covid-19 pandemic has reinforced humanity’s dependence on modern tech, but the same tools that enable remote working are also being used to spread disinformation and perpetuate cybercrime. Ambivalence towards technology is nothing new.

Cover image credit: Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images

node.text:
In the past couple of weeks South Africa has witnessed the worst violence since the end of apartheid in 1994. Our correspondent in Johannesburg explains what he has seen on the streets and why the country is in crisis. 

Cover credit: Getty Images

node.title: South Africa: what's behind the riots?

node.text:
In America, the intelligence services deem far-right extremism a greater domestic threat than Islamist terrorism. The pandemic has exacerbated the spread of white supremacism and neo-Nazism.

Cover image credit: Michael Nigro/Pacific Press/LightRocket via Getty Images

node.title: Fortnite to far right: the rise of digital extremism

node.text:
Across much of the world, covid-19 restrictions are starting to ease. The Economist has crunched the data to calculate how close countries are to pre-pandemic levels of normality—but will life ever be the same again? 

Click on the link in our bio to visit our website and explore our interactive normalcy tracker. It covers 50 countries which account for 76% of the world’s population and 90% of its GDP.

Cover image credit: Lluis Gene/AFP via Getty Images

node.title: Covid-19: why your life will never be the same again

node.text:
“The world doesn’t wait for America to sort out its domestic challenges.” Zanny Minton Beddoes, The Economist’s editor-in-chief, tells our “Checks and Balance” podcast that the Biden administration is wrong to deprioritise foreign policy.⁠
⁠
America set out to reshape the world order after the attacks of September 11th. Today it is easy to conclude that its foreign policy has been abandoned on a runway at Kabul airport. Is the era of American interventionism over? ⁠
⁠
The Economist's James Bennet traces Joe Biden’s shifting views on foreign wars. We look back to the origins of humanitarian interventionism in Bosnia. And, Anne-Marie Slaughter, former aide to Barack Obama and author of “Renewal: From Crisis to Transformation in Our Lives, Work and Politics”, tells us how American power might work in the future.⁠
⁠
Click the link in our bio to listen to our podcast on democracy in America

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 11, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"The The world after 9/11 meant that American Muslims were careful in ways they had not needed to be before Farah Pandith'.

node.text:
Scars and emotional damage run deep for American Muslims who experienced the anger, prejudice, isolation, violence and societal unease following 9/11, says Farah Pandith.⁠
⁠
Writing for The Economist, the Muslim former American official recounts "the period of fear, bigotry and name-calling" that American Muslims experienced before 9/11, and argues that while the community has enjoyed many triumphs since, it has been "a hard 20 years".⁠
⁠
"Although on the surface, American Muslims have fared well since 9/11, below the successes and behind the smiles is something else," Ms Pandith argues.⁠
⁠
"For those who grew up as American Muslims after 9/11, they never knew a time when they were not questioned about their faith, culture or heritage," she adds. ⁠
⁠
"American Muslims continue to this day to think about who they are, how they belong to the whole, how to raise their kids and what they can do to make sure they are safe. Whereas before, American Muslims were not forced to consider those aspects of identity, in post 9/11 America they had to."⁠
⁠
To read why Ms Pandith believes that the success of American Muslims is built on pain and resilience, click on the link in our bio.⁠
⁠
Illustration: @dan.will

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 11, 2021. May be an image of text that says '"The The world after 9/11 meant that American Muslims were careful in ways they had not needed to be before Farah Pandith'.
Photo by The Economist on September 11, 2021. May be a closeup of 1 person.
Photo by The Economist on September 11, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Will anything ever be the same? In the days after 9/11, when all were stunned, it was clear the world had changed profoundly. Less obvious was just how far the geopolitical shockwaves would reach.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
This is a visual history of how the world has changed—as told through 20 years of our covers.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In our first issue after the assault we likened the moment to the attack on Pearl Harbour. We called for America, and its allies, to offer up a response that remained “measured”. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
By late 2003 the invasion of Iraq had proved swift and overwhelming, but it was soon obvious much had gone wrong. Investigators found no sign of Saddam Hussein’s supposed weapons of mass destruction. We asked if George W. Bush and Tony Blair had lied to justify war. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Now in 2021, the rapid collapse of the American-backed government in Kabul, and the swift return of the Taliban, marks a humiliating end to a difficult period.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
To read more about each of these covers, and how America's role in the world has changed, click the link in our bio.

node.text:
As New Yorkers commemorate the 20th anniversary of 9/11, they are also contemplating how to recover from covid-19.

After the attacks of 2001, New York came back stronger—so what lessons can its leaders learn from that success to help the city bounce back today?

Cover image credit: Gary Hershorn/Getty Images

Bush 40 60 80 100 Barack Obama Donald Trump Joe Biden *September 4th-7th 2021 Source: YouGov/ The Economist The Economist'.

node.text:
It is clear is that 20 years after the 9/11 attacks, the scars on America’s psyche have not healed.⁠
⁠
A plurality of Americans (43%) believe the “war on terror” has been worth it, according to a new poll by YouGov on behalf of The Economist. Few are confident that Joe Biden, America’s president, is equipped to carry on the fight.⁠
⁠
Such views are not confined to Republicans.⁠
⁠
The results suggest that the threat of terrorism remains politically salient, but also that Americans views on what to do about it remain confused and led by events. Far more Americans, for instance, believe that Donald Trump’s policies made America safer than Joe Biden’s, despite the lack of jihadist attacks on American soil during either administration. This view, which in part reflects Mr Biden’s handling of the Afghanistan withdrawal, may reverse over time.⁠
⁠
Tap the link in our bio to explore our interactive poll tracker that looks at Americans’ opinions on a range of issues.

node.text:
After the attacks of September 11th, President George W. Bush declared that the world was either with America or against it.⁠
⁠
For a while, America appeared to have uncontested power—and there have been enduring achievements since then. ⁠
⁠
Counter-terrorism efforts have improved: Osama bin Laden is dead and no remotely comparable attack on America has succeeded. ⁠
⁠
But for the most part the legacy of the response to 9/11 has been a bitter one. The forever wars in Afghanistan and Iraq came at a huge human and fiscal cost. Mr Biden's debacle in Kabul makes a grim epilogue.⁠
⁠
The mire in the Middle East has been a distraction from the real story of the early 21st century, the rise of China. ⁠
⁠
But the national mood of fatigue and apathy is a poor guide to America’s future role in the world. ⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read why how effective foreign policy can stop the superpower swinging from hubris to muddle. ⁠
⁠
Cover credit: The Economist

node.text:
Researchers have found a strong statistical link between patriarchy and violent political instability.⁠
⁠
A study by Texas A&M and Brigham Young universities ranked 176 countries on a scale of 0 to 16 for what they call the “patrilineal/fraternal syndrome”.⁠
⁠
This is a composite of such things as unequal treatment of women in family law and property rights, early marriage for girls, patrilocal marriage, polygamy, bride price, son preference, violence against women and social attitudes towards it.⁠
⁠
As this chart shows, rich democracies do well; Australia, Sweden and Switzerland all manage the best-possible score of zero. Iraq scores a woeful 15, level with Nigeria, Yemen and (pre-Taliban) Afghanistan. Only South Sudan does worse.⁠
⁠
But dismal scores are not limited to poor countries, nor to Muslim ones. The authors estimate that 120 countries are still to some degree swayed by this syndrome.⁠
⁠
Misogyny comes at a cost. To read how the most sexist societies work, and why oppressing women hurts men, too, click on the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist in Qatar. May be an image of 1 person, standing and text that says 'Middle East & Africa America's exit from Kabul has been a diplomatic boon for tiny Qatar T'.

node.text:
“No country has done more than Qatar,” said President Joe Biden’s secretary of state, Antony Blinken. It was better publicity than any pricey lobbying contract could buy.⁠
⁠
Of the 120,000 people America flew out of Afghanistan, almost half passed through the Al-Udeid airbase in Qatar. Mr Biden called Qatar’s emir, Tamim bin Hamad Al Thani, to thank him.⁠
⁠
Prior to the evacuation, Qatar mediated talks between the Taliban and America. The group set up a diplomatic mission in the Qatari capital in 2013.⁠
⁠
The tiny emirate thus played a central role in the beginning of the end, and the end itself. ⁠
⁠
The question, however, is how long Qatar’s influence will endure. Click on the link in our bio to read how the country hopes to maintain leverage.⁠
⁠
Credit: Qatar's Government Communication/Getty Images

node.text:
⁠Since 2001 the American Muslim community has more than doubled in size, to 3.5m. And its prominence in American life has increased exponentially. ⁠
⁠
Muslims are one of America’s most educated religious groups. More than 15% of doctors in Michigan are Muslim, though less than 3% of the state’s population is.⁠
⁠
Anti-Muslim sentiment has become entrenched among Republicans. Covid-19 provides a powerful image.⁠
⁠
Anti-vaxxer Trump voters who are now likeliest to be hospitalised with the disease tend to be the most anti-Muslim Americans. The doctors treating them are quite likely to be Muslim.⁠
⁠
The bigotry of the right reflects its members’ lost status. Meanwhile Muslims will continue to rise. Tap the link in our bio to read more.⁠
⁠
Credit: New York Times / Redux / eyevine

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by The Economist on September 10, 2021. May be an image of child, standing and outdoors.

node.text:
What 9/11 was like for Afghans? Payenda Sargand, a journalist from Kabul, reflects. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
“Everything about that day was stupefying: that the planes were flying into the buildings, that it was somehow linked to us...we had never heard of Osama bin Laden or al-Qaeda.”⁠⁠
⁠⁠
In October 2001 when the Americans made good on their threat and invaded Afghanistan, life changed completely in Kabul. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
“It was extraordinary to see all these white people with their uniforms, as though aliens had come from Mars...We didn’t have sunglasses before 9/11; we’d never seen a kettle before, and people couldn’t stop talking about the fact that it switched off by itself when it boiled.”⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Some in Kabul are furious with the Americans for “handing Kabul over to the Taliban”, while others are more optimistic. Whichever side turns out to be right, Afghanistan cannot go back to how it was 20 years ago. Click the link in bio to read more.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Images: @andrewquilty / Magnum⁠

node.text:
“The ‘forever war’ waged by America in Afghanistan put a strain on relations with Pakistan,” writes Maleeha Lodhi, Pakistan’s former ambassador to the United States, in a piece for The Economist.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Ms Lodhi argues that Pakistan has borne the brunt of America’s mistakes in Afghanistan. “Americans ignored how the conflict had already spilled over to destabilise Pakistan and exact a heavy cost in lives, inflicting dire social and economic consequences, including terrorist attacks inside Pakistan,” she argues. ⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Now both Pakistan and America must decide how they will deal with the Taliban, a choice that will have consequences far beyond their own borders. Tap the link in our bio to read what Ms Lodhi thinks about the tortured Pakistani-American relationship and what America must learn from its missteps in Asia.⁠⁠
⁠⁠
Credit: @dan.will

node.text:
The horror of that day—September 11th 2001—unified America. It also seemed to offer the prospect of global solidarity. ⁠
⁠
“The world has changed in a way that we are all vulnerable,” said Joe Biden, the chairman of the Senate foreign-relations committee, the following day.⁠
⁠
A few weeks later, he imagined how that new purpose “could shape this half-century as the cold war shaped the last”. A big claim. ⁠
⁠
Twenty years on, the world is not the one Joe Biden hoped for, in which America and China shared interests in fighting terrorism. ⁠
⁠
America’s post-9/11 mission in the world has failed to strengthen an international order that conforms to America’s values.⁠
⁠
The way in which Mr Biden has ended the wars of 9/11 by withdrawing from Afghanistan does mark the end, for now, of a faded idea, about the imperative of spreading America’s ideals throughout the world.⁠
⁠
Click on the link in our bio to read our briefing this week, which argues that America wasted the influence it had after the events of two decades ago. ⁠
⁠
Credit: @elliefp
